text: Anyone come up with good ways to get a better page speed for a HubSpot cos site??
Do we only need to load current.js once on a page if we have multiple CTAs? Can we async one?
I think one is sufficient
I'd assume it's a single library with the .load function (which wouldn't change between calls on the same page)
not one library per CTA :X Imagine!
<https://knowledge.HubSpot.com/articles/kcs_article/cos-general/how-can-i-optimize-my-HubSpot-site-for-google-pagespeed-insights>
<https://knowledge.HubSpot.com/articles/kcs_article/reports/how-do-i-improve-the-page-load-time-for-my-website>
I FOUND THESE TWO, which basically say put shit in footer and the standard head includes stays
Does anyone know what font was used to create the inbound logo?
<@U25PYL3Q8> are there specific domains/issues youâ€™re trying to address?
<@U6TBZ66FN> ^
No, just trying to get an idea on how to get a better page speed score for google page insights. Everything is in teh 50s when it is in HubSpot and that just doesn't go well with clients

<@U25PYL3Q8> I am working on combining call the CSS in the document head. It should gain some page speed point. In the long term, we have plans to make HubSpot pages to get a page speed insights score in the 80s. Stay tuned.
Do clients even understand what that means? Or are they just saying "Google says it's slow so it must be slow"?
<@U26C29XPH> we have some SAAS clients that are heavily involved
Ahh ok. Just was curious cuz I know how clients can be lol
when we do site audits we talk about this
its much nicer when we are auditing them pre HubSpot
and the score is under 50, "oh yes, this one will be better!"
My understanding from Developer Day is that a lot of the issues that popup aren't anything we can do on our end. It's stuff that has to be fixed on HubSpot's side.
<@U6TBZ66FN> Thanks for this. I appreciate your hard work on it. Do you have an estimated timeline on when to expect this?
I'm assuming jquery gets loaded in the head because people will have too many errors if they dont -- an option to load it in footer or NOT load it would be great
*placed in content settings
They talked about why they can't just switch it to the footer right now but sounded like support for it is in the works.
We will start rolling out combining css in the following weeks. Other improvements are still in the planning, so no timeline yet.
thanks <@U6TBZ66FN>
WHILE we are on teh subject, will HubSpot be serving pages via http2 any time soon?
Yes, maybe http2 is happening right now for your site. You should be able to check it.
<@U38EZFVFE> uploaded a file: <https://HubSpotdev.slack.com/files/U38EZFVFE/F7PENGDLN/screen_shot_2017-10-23_at_2.38.57_pm.jpg|Screen Shot 2017-10-23 at 2.38.57 PM.jpg>
<@U38EZFVFE> looks like it's definitely a case by case basis. I just ran our own website that's hosted on HubSpot and it said it does not support it.
I think it is the new system they are switching everyone too.
Yeah with the new SSL stuff as well
That is why they are placing everyone on auto ssl cause they are switching to http2
We are in the process to enable everyone for http2. It may take a few weeks.

So, another factor in google pagespeed insights -- it doesn't check properly for http2 so even if we have a site on http2 in HubSpot, the way pagespeed processes it, it doesn't take advantage of parallel loading / push
<@U25PYL3Q8> uploaded a file: <https://HubSpotdev.slack.com/files/U25PYL3Q8/F7PMBTE6T/pasted_image_at_2017_10_23_03_21_pm.png|this is using the audits feature in google chrome dev tools>
And then i used dareboost (first http2 tester I found) <https://www.dareboost.com/en/comparison/59ee413d0cf224d151e613ad/59ee413d0cf224d151e613ae/>
On teh onpointconsulting
I was hoping it would fix some of those css and js issues on http2 BUT it looks like that the http2 is actually slower
which may be because we are still loading less amount of larger files instead of changing to a lot more smaller files
I feel changing the way scripts combine will negatively affect http2 performance
and if HS is moving to that direction, it may improve pagespeed insights performance, but it will actually be worse off in the http2 world

The goal for HS is not to improve the pagespeed insights score, it is to improve the performance of the web pages. We will use pagespeed insights score as a guide, but will not hurt the performance just to improve the score.

okay, so with that being said, and the way HTTP 2 works, combining and minimizing CSS into one large file is based on http 1 work arounds -- and doesn't take advantage of http2 parallel calls. It would seem that HS would want to do this combining for http1 clients and remove that from http2 -- BUT i'm not server master, I just understand a little bit about the tech and the way the http protocol works
<@U25PYL3Q8> but the water falls look amazing!
<@U6TBZ66FN> on the domain <https://www.onpointconsultingllc.com> the new messages app is throwing a 404 error. I am not sure why since they are not using it.
Thanks for report this. I will take a look at why the messages app is requested. Thanks.
